articles.content:
The much-rumored DJI Air 3 has officially been announced, and the fourth installment of the Air range is the first of the market leader’s mid-size drones to sport dual cameras.
Sitting between the b… [+4265 chars]
articles.paraphrased_content: DJI has also rolled out its latest and next-level O4 video transmission, which boasts a range of up to 12.4 miles / 20km in low interference environments with 1080p / 60fps live feed.Another first for the Air series is the inclusion of Omnidirectional obstacle sensing, as found in advanced-level Mavic 3 drones.It works using twin fisheye lenses for forwards, back, left, right, and upward sensing, plus binocular lenses on the underside, with 'APAS 5.0' anti-collision kicking in to avoid any detected obstacles.(Image credit: DJI)Are two better than one?The DJI Air 3 has two 1/1.3-inch quad-Bayer sensors with dual native ISO that are capable of shooting 48MP photos and 4K slow-motion video up to 100 fps, or 4K HDR up to 60fps.If you’d like to find out how this latest mid-size aerial camera fares in real-world use, and discover more about its features, including those not covered here, we’ve already published our full DJI Air 3 review.(Image credit: DJI)DJI Air 3 price and release dateDJI Air 3 (DJI RC-N2) costs $1,099 / £962 / AU$1,699DJI AIr 3 Fly More Combo (RC 2) is $1,549 / £1,379 / AU$2,349The list price of the DJI Air 3 with basic DJI RC-N2 controller is $1,099 / £962 / AU$1,699, while the Fly More Combo (with the same RC-N2) is $1,349 / £1,199 / AU$2,049.It’s an altogether more versatile setup than the Air 2S, which relies on an older, but physically larger 1-inch sensor with 20MP still images and 5.4K / 30p video, and it could well be that the Air 2S remains on the market a little while longer given the clear distinction between the two models.One thing’s for sure: DJI has further cemented its position as the market leader in consumer drone technology.(Image credit: DJI)Flight delight: longer, further, saferThe overall flight experience of the 720g, C1-rated (EU) drone has been improved, with a larger-capacity 4,241mAh battery enabling a maximum flight time of 46 minutes.So we’ve seen the tech before, but not in this combination, or in the Air series of drones.There are several optional accessories, too, including the Battery Charging Hub ($69 / £59 / AU$129), and spare parts including a pair of Low-Noise Propellers ($12 / £11 / AU$39), while an additional Intelligent Flight Battery costs $159 / £129 / AU$359DJI Air 3: first wordWe couldn’t have predicted the tech utilized by the Air 3; it’s an excellent update from the Air 2S, and sensibly positioned between the entry-level Mini series and advanced Mavic series, having more in common with the latter.Some will be disappointed there's smaller image sensors inside than the one in the Air 2S, but the Air 3 is undoubtedly a more versatile offering.The much-rumored DJI Air 3 has officially been announced, and the fourth installment of the Air range is the first of the market leader’s mid-size drones to sport dual cameras.Sitting between the beginner-friendly Mini 3 series of drones and the advanced-level Mavic 3 series, the DJI Air 3 is the latest and greatest option for beginners looking to upgrade to a bigger and better flight experience, and is a comprehensive replacement for the single-camera Air 2S.Not only does the Air 3 pack the same 24mm camera as the Mini 3 Pro, and now the 70mm telephoto camera recently unveiled in the Mavic 3 Pro; it benefits from a significantly bigger battery that extends the maximum flight time, and improved flight-safety features.It’s a massive Air-series update at a negligible mark-up over its predecessor, and instantly becomes one of our best drones for aerial photography.There’s also the usual Return To Home (RTH), which rounds out the industry-leading safety features.That’s a huge increase over the Air 2S's 31 minutes, and has blown even our most optimistic Air 3 expectations out of the water – we predicted 40 minutes would be the absolute max.Full HD video is up to 200fps – that's 8x slow-motion – while there's also an option to shoot uncropped vertical 2.7K video up to 60fps.One sensor is paired with a 24mm f/1.7 camera, which is the same as the one used in the Mini 3 Pro, and the other is a 70mm f/2.8, which is effectively a 3x telephoto camera, inherited from the Mavic 3 Pro.Another Fly More Combo includes the more expensive RC 2 controller, which features a built-in screen, and costs $1,549 / £1,379 / AU$2,349.That's twice the 6.2-mile / 10km range of the O3+ video transmission used in the Mavic 3 series of drones and the Mini 3 Pro.

articles.author: Vjeran Pavic
articles.title: Drones are becoming boring
articles.description: DJI Air 3 drone flies longer and further and captures the world around you with two lenses.
articles.content:
DJI Air 3 review: old ideas, new package
DJI Air 3 review: old ideas, new package
 / DJI Air 3 comes with two lenses, 46 minutes of flight time, and a familiar look.
ByVjeran Pavic, a supervising … [+6620 chars]
articles.paraphrased_content:
It’s still a very capable drone that does many things right but also just a little bit uninspiring.Will 360 cameras make their way here?And no, this drone won’t flip its camera 90 degrees to let you film in true 4K vertically.No?Or maybe we start with a single backward camera?I haven’t noticed any major issues here, like I did with the batteries during my Mini 3 Pro review.Battery life is pretty much the same across the whole lineup now, which is to say it’s about 45 minutes, give or take.Before you get mad at me for this hot take, let’s set the record straight: the Air 3 is a fantastic drone.I do wish DJI gave us both options.DJI also lists a 48MP photo mode, but I have not been able to find it in its usual place in the menu.At its core, the Air 3 is just a recycling of old ideas we’ve already seen in other DJI products.Through a recent software update, DJI quietly replaced D-Log with D-Log M in the Air 2S drone, too.As for photos, this drone takes 12MP photos, and they look good.And it’s called the Air 3, and yes, all the rumors have been true.The usual 24mm drone footage started to get repetitive, so I’m glad we’re getting more variety these days.I’m ready for something new.But don’t get me wrong: I’d rather pay $1,099 than the $2,199 the Mavic 3 Pro demands, whose third lens, a 7x telephoto zoom, didn’t impress me much.I have reached out to DJI about this.It’s a combination of old ideas we’ve already seen.Could we get built-in ND filters?The ISO of 400 (left) still looks very decent, but photos do lose a lot of detail at maxed out ISO of 6400 (right)

And outside of those two lenses, there really isn’t much else to discuss if you’re familiar with DJI’s existing lineup.The Air 3 range is rated for 20km (12 miles), but in practice (and legally), you won’t be able to take advantage of that.Or, even even better, variable aperture?DJI also replaced its D-Log color profile for a less flat variant called D-Log M. It’s easier to color grade, and it doesn’t require filming at high ISO like the D-Log, but it also has noticeably less dynamic range.But the compression in the image alone is worth it, and the parallax effect is great.Here’s a question for you: do any of these changes make you super excited?Between $1,099 (with the new controller) or $1,349 (for the Fly More Combo), it slots in nicely between the Mini and the Mavic 3.Night mode, which was introduced at the end of 2022 for the Mavic 3, found its way to the new Air 3 as well.It’s time, DJI.It’s similar to the camera found in the Mini 3 Pro, which has the same 1/1.3-inch sensor and the same max aperture.But don’t fret — the image quality is still great.But now it’s up to you to decide if you want a sub 250g drone with proper vertical filming like the Mini, the better image quality from the larger sensor in the Mavic 3, or the versatility of the Air 3.But I do have two minor complaints about the Air 3’s telephoto camera.7Verge ScoreDJI Air 3$1099The GoodVersatile camera Great battery Great low-light performanceThe BadKind of boringHeavier than beforeSmaller main sensor than Air 2S$1099 at Amazon$1099 at DJIHow we rate and review products

That was my first worry here, and it might be for you, too.What about adjustable aperture trickling down from the Mavic 3 series?The Air 3 can film in 4K 60, and compared to the Air 2S, this drone won’t crop your footage.Both lenses are capable of capturing beautiful airborne images.With a larger f/1.7 aperture lens, the main sensor performs better in low light.It’s a capable flying camera that improves on a few things from its predecessor but makes do with a smaller image sensor than before.The Air 3 is a capable, if uninspiring, drone

And that’s the Air 3.There isn’t much new here that would make you incredibly excited to go out and get flying.Or even better, something we’ve all been wanting for oh so long — built-in ND filters.Let me explain.DJI’s OcuSync connectivity system is upgraded, but I haven’t had major connection issues in years.Don’t expect stunning bokeh here.That means that once I switch from the main lens with f/1.7 aperture to the f/2.8 tele lens, I’ll likely have to raise the ISO, which in turn introduces more noise into my clips.It takes full advantage of either sensor.For one, the footage can look a bit flat.Secondly, as someone who desperately wants to extract the best possible image quality from any of my cameras, I aim to film at the lowest ISO possible while maintaining proper shutter speed (double the frame rate).You’ll be happy with what you get here, and DJI’s RAW files leave plenty of information to manipulate in the editing process.The new $1,099 and up drone from DJI has two cameras, 46 minutes of battery life, improved connectivity with Ocusync 4, a brand-new controller, and a brand-new design resembling the recently released Mavic 3 and Mavic 3 Pro.I’d love to see something new next year.What I’d love to see are some after-market ND filters that can compensate for that aperture difference and make switching between two lenses seamless.The main lens comes with a larger f/1.7 aperture, while the new 70mm lens has max aperture of f/2.8.Instead, it’s lets you film open gate instead of simply cropping your horizontal footage.Same here.Did DJI sacrifice image quality in favor of some versatility?The Air 3 is eligible for Europe’s C1 drone classification.There is some but not a lot of separation between the foreground and the background.There’s a new controller, and it’s just as good as the last one.PreviousNext1/7PreviousNext1/7

The second 3x telephoto lens has a smaller f/2.8 aperture, and it is the same telephoto lens that you’ll find in the Mavic 3 Pro that came out recently.The drone world’s worst-kept secret is out.Photography by Vjeran Pavic / The VergeA solid compromise, but I really wish it did flip the camera, though.In fact, almost every feature works on both lenses (including Active Track, Night Mode, 4K 60, and 4K 100fps), except vertical mode, which is to be expected.On the company’s forums, a DJI rep said that it was just a “naming convention problem,” but it still got a lot of pilots mad.It’s just not practical.One hardware thing you’ll immediately notice is the drone’s audible noise.It lets you increase your ISO up to 12800 from the usual 6400 limit in the normal filming mode.It’s a small complaint, but it does take away from the filming experience.Presumably, it will come later with a firmware update.It’s rated for 81 dB, which is still loud, but due to the propellers’ larger size, they produce a lower frequency, bassier sound, which isn’t as piercing as before.And at this point, I think it’s becoming clear why this drone is a bit underwhelming.Aside from the filming settings, it seems like there is some in-camera noise reduction applied to the footage as well.

articles.author: Craig Hale
articles.title: Google's new plan for the future of the web has a lot of people worried - here's why
articles.description: A proposed Web Environment Integrity API may soon require you to run specific software to get access to websites.
articles.content:
The Internet is going crazy (while it still can) over a Google proposition that could see some form of DRM reach websites in years to come.
The Web Environment Integrity Explainer, authored by four … [+1977 chars]
articles.paraphrased_content:
The Internet is going crazy (while it still can) over a Google proposition that could see some form of DRM reach websites in years to come.The Web Environment Integrity Explainer, authored by four Google workers and hosted on a GitHub page, introduces the idea that a website could be able to “request a token that attests key facts about the environment their client code is running in” in order to ascertain trust over the visitor and their browser session, and thus grant access.The authors claim that a Web Environment Integrity API would “allow web servers to evaluate the authenticity of the device,” but many unhappy Internet users see it as nothing more than a form of DRM.Google evaluating your device?Passing an “environment attestation” test would give users a “IntegrityToken” under the proposed scheme, indicating that the requesting environment is unmodified and as such, clean.Read more> These are the best privacy tools and anonymous browsers

> Google Chrome's cookie-replacing tools are set for launch

> Raising concerns over Google Authenticator’s new featuresThe Android Play Integrity API already does this to check that your device has not been rooted.Some apps, including banking apps and a number of video streaming apps like Netflix, already use this to block access from rooted devices over cybersecurity fears and an effort to protect sensitive information.Google, or at least the workers behind this particular explainer, “strongly feel” that device IDs and other unique identifiers should not be included.Instead, they see it as a tool to detect and prevent social media fake engagement, non-human traffic, phishing campaigns, bulk hijacking attempts, and other malicious activity.Since the explainer, the repo’s GitHub issues forum has been awash with complaints, with one calling the idea “unethical and against the open web.” Another calls it a violation of the W3C’s code of ethics, “Positive Work Environment at W3C: Code of Ethics and Professional Conduct,” calling it out for its discriminatory nature, while another suggests forcing individuals to run specific software could be a matter for EU investigation.Google did not immediately respond to our request for further comment on the proposed Web Environment Integrity API.Any update will be posted here.Check out the best VPNs for greater online freedom
